title: Facebook's Sandberg Pushes Back On Antitrust Allegations
text: Sheryl Sandberg, chief operations officer of Facebook, is pushing back against two antitrust lawsuits filed against the social media giant, CNBC reported on Friday (Dec. 11). The lawsuits filed this week could break up Facebook's ownership of Instagram, acquired in 2012, and WhatsApp, snapped up in 2014.

title: Why Investors Need to Look Beyond Facebook's Legal Troubles
text: Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ:FB) is once again facing the wrath of regulators. On Dec. 10, the Federal Trade Commission announced the filing of several lawsuits against the company, primarily attacking its dominant position in the social media industry.

title: Sandberg: Facebook antitrust lawsuits will have 'big chilling problem for American business'
text: Sandberg also argued against the notion that Facebook does not face competition.

title: Big tech firms to face 6% fines if breach new EU content rules
text: Big tech firms such as Google and Facebook will face fines of up to 6% of turnover if they do not do more to tackle illegal content and reveal more about advertising on their platforms under draft European Union rules.

title: Why Loup Ventures' Gene Munster says to be more selective about which FAANG stocks you own
text: Mega-cap tech companies led the market higher through most of 2020. Is it time for the next generation of growth stocks to take the lead?

title: These are the key arguments in the antitrust case against Facebook
text: Even if the case against a company is compelling, breaking up monopolies is hard to do. The Federal Trade Commission and the state attorneys general have a good shot at proving Facebook is a dangerous monopoly that should be broken up.

title: The Facebook Complaints Highlight The Limits Of Antitrust
text: Pro-competitive remedies are unlikely to improve privacy or content moderation

title: Facebook's alleged use of APIs to crush competition is a warning to other data companies
text: Forget Instagram and WhatsApp. The real villains in the FTC lawsuit are Facebook's abuse of data and APIs.

title: Mark Zuckerberg told Facebook employees they won't need a COVID-19 vaccine when they return to the office next summer
text: Facebook employees won't need a COVID shot to come into work. CEO Mark Zuckerberg told employees in a virtual company all-hands on Thursday the company won't require they get a COVID-19 vaccine in order to return to the office, a source told The Daily Beast.

title: The antitrust case against Facebook: Here's what you need to know
text: The US government just opened another big new front on the techlash.
